<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_:
```c
size_t
MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (char *str,
                                      bool *broken_encoding)
{
#ifdef MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE
  size_t len;
  size_t res;

  len = strlen (str);
  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_ (str, len, str, len, broken_encoding);
  str[res] = 0;

  return res;
#else  /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
  size_t r;
  size_t w;
  if (NULL != broken_encoding)
    *broken_encoding = false;
  r = 0;
  w = 0;
  while (0 != str[r])
  {
    const char chr = str[r++];
    if ('%' == chr)
    {
      const char d1 = str[r++];
      if (0 == d1)
      {
        if (NULL != broken_encoding)
          *broken_encoding = true;
        str[w++] = chr; /* Copy "as is" */
        str[w] = 0;
        return w;
      }
      else
      {
        const char d2 = str[r++];
        if (0 == d2)
        {
          if (NULL != broken_encoding)
            *broken_encoding = true;
          str[w++] = chr; /* Copy "as is" */
          str[w++] = d1; /* Copy "as is" */
          str[w] = 0;
          return w;
        }
        else
        {
          const int h = toxdigitvalue (d1);
          const int l = toxdigitvalue (d2);
          unsigned char out;
          if ((0 > h) || (0 > l))
          {
            if (NULL != broken_encoding)
              *broken_encoding = true;
            str[w++] = chr; /* Copy "as is" */
            str[w++] = d1;
            str[w++] = d2;
            continue;
          }
          out =
            (unsigned char) (((uint8_t) (((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) h)) << 4))
                             | ((uint8_t) ((unsigned int) l)));
          str[w++] = (char) out;
          continue;
        }
      }
    }
    str[w++] = chr;
  }
  str[w] = 0;
  return w;
#endif /* ! MHD_FAVOR_SMALL_CODE */
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: res = MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_ (str, len, str, len, broken_encoding);
explanation: Only the small-code path contains calls to functions from <string.h>. The call to strlen(...) is a direct use of a <string.h> function and must be investigated to ensure it does not read past the bounds of the object pointed to by str (e.g. if str is not NUL-terminated). The subsequent use of the returned length (passed into MHD_str_pct_decode_lenient_n_) and the write to str[res] depend on that length and therefore should be reviewed together with the strlen usage. All other code fragments in the function do not call any <string.h> functions: the main decoding loop performs explicit indexed accesses and explicit NUL ('\0') checks and does not invoke standard string-handling routines covered by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Those indexed accesses, while potentially relevant to other MISRA rules (bounds checking, pointer validity), are not subject to Rule 21.17 and thus are not listed as suspicious for this specific rule.
